Posts.Content: Hi Nice Cuppa It did calm down and now i've stopped my infections its stopped altogether thankfully.  I hope it never gets worse than that - that was only my first EC round  - i don't know if the others will be similar or worse. Next one Friday - i'm going to enjoy these few normal days as much as i can! xxx
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Ok so first one down.  Pretty horrible first day and now third day bearable.. I have to start with the injections for white blood cells tonight. Has anyone had them? The list of SE looks as horrid as chemo. also has anyone here tried fasting? Apparently it makes SE better and also chemo more effective. I felt like I was hit by a freight train so not sure if it was worth all the 36 hours of pain.. i will have 4 x EC at two weekly intervals and then 12 paclitaxel every week. Anyone else doing/had the same with words of advice?  Im wondering how I will ever make it!  Thanks all
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Thanks so much Mary so good to hear another voice. Yes it’s what’s called dense dose as I had a particularly large load (all 28 nodes). I’m trying to find someone who’s gone through it.  I will keep popping around and checking.  Well done you for getting through! Everyone is amazing on here and I hope I will get into the swing of it somehow..  thanks again for answering!
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Also, while i'm here,  i can see that this has appeared in other places on this site but if you don't know about it you wouldn't search for it. For those worried about nail issues there seems to be pretty solid research this works better than anything..  http://polybalm.com I've ordered some as i'll be doing 12 weeks on Taxol which apparently really buggers up your nails.  I'll let you know how i go..  xxxxxx
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hey Nice cuppa i literally logged now on to see if anyone had back spasms too! Mine strarted last night (day 10 first chemo) and exactly the same thing- lower back stabbing pains. I worried it might have been kidneys but I can get into positions where it doesn’t hurt and I have no temperature or urinary symptoms. I found lying on my side with a big pillow between my knees worked. And also massaging with a tennis ball against a wall either side of the spine.  What new and wonderful pains will come up next??? I hope your pain and mine buggers off soon. Let me know if you hear anything from docs. I will mention this on Wednesday to mine.
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hello - I'm with you! starting on Friday - here we go - i wish you strength and luck!
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Thanks so much love!   Yes i will try to focus on all the SE passing - Good to see you are through the other end and i will also have the shadow to fight when this is through of 'will it come back' but i've heard many amazing people talking of how it does settle down and you live in the moment much much more.  So i look forward to that.  Much love!
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: sorry - that was to Nice Cuppa!
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi Aliblue firat day was horrific and then got less shit each day.. althoughnow on day 5 I seemed to have slipped backwards but I’m still up and out.. good to hear from you, and all you other amazing women.  This is just hideous but every time I read someone else going through it I think: OK this has to be possible to get through because so many have. Im trying to put a brave face on but can admit here im terrified.. what’s the next side effect, how bad will the next chemo be and will I ever ever be myself again?   I wish you were all here to hug! Thank you all!

Posts.Content: Moocow that was so lovely it made me weep until snot fell onto my keyboard.. I’m printing it out and keeping it.. (your comment, not my snot)  big love

Posts.Content: PS - are you on the injections (Filgrastim) to raise your white blood cells?  Because that's what my guess is - it causes bone pain as a pretty common side effect

Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi Kathleen I'm not a professional so only from my own research!   The whole chemistry of diet and cancer cells is massively complex I went looking for answers, looked at a zillion research papers to find some magic diet, some superfood, some guarantee i could  get rid of cancer and not have a reoccurrence, but after all this it seems a balanced healthy diet rich in tons of veg, fibre and with no refined sugars still seems boring to be the basis of it all - that along with exercise and finding something that you can be happy with for the rest of your life. Crash diets are bad as they affect metabolism, blood sugars etc which really need to be kept steady.  If you can't sustain a way of eating and then start gaining again its an even more unhealthy picture. I have seen negative comments about getting all your calorie intake from fats in a very low carb (or 'keto') diet, some of them (like Omega 6 from meats) have been shown to boost oestrogen production (though in animals only).  There are claims that a 'keto' diet is the ultimate 'anti cancer' diet but when i got excited by this and look at the actual science there's not really enough evidence for it and a fair amount that looks the other way, saturated fats and estrogen doesn't look a good mix. This is a little article that might be of interest: https://www.mdanderson.org/publications/cancerwise/the-keto-diet-and-cancer--what-patients-should-know.h00-159223356.html I also found this site helpful if you want to do your own research -  it has links to all the latest research on diet and breast cancer - including what you should and shouldn't eat during different types of chemo and also for each different type of BC.  https://foodforbreastcancer.com/amp Apologies for the nerdy load of info - and just again - i'm not an expert but just wanted to share what i've been through in case it helps anyone else looking!   Broccoli anyone??
Posts.Title: Guys, in a bit of a panic regarding diet - of all things!!!

Posts.Content: Whoops and just want to add that i'm taking B12, B6, vitamin E and L-glutamine to try to protect against peripheral Neuropathy - this was suggested by my oncologist in a "some people take this but there's no real proof' I looked up research papers and there's enough early positive research to convince me to try and no evidence to suggest it interfere's with chemo (but always tell your Onco if you are taking anything).   I will let you know how i get on
Posts.Title: **MAY 2019 BREAST CANCER CHEMOTHERAPY CHAT**

Posts.Content: Hello all - its been a while but i'm still here.  Been through 4 x EC every 2 weeks and am on 3 of my 12 weekly Paclitaxel.    I'm sharing any tips i've found in case anyone else benefits.  I found EC awful but mainly because of the Filgrastim injections that i needed to give myself to get my white blood cell count up.  They reduced it from 10-8 of the two week period because my side effects from it (breathlessness, liquid in lungs, depression and weakness) were so bad.  If you are suffering similarly tell them - they will reduce if possible.   Other EC side effects after first 2 days of tiredness and a bit of nausea not too bad (i stopped all my anti-sickness meds by day 3 as i wasn't feeling sick and taking them gave me constipation for days!) - taste was disgusting particularly water - so sparkling water worked for me - as did drinking water stored in a copper pan. Adding a tiny (1/4 teaspoon) of honey to savoury foods somehow also seemed to help.  Porridge and soups seemed to be the best foods for not getting any upsets for the first few days following chemo.  I would stick to mainly vegetarian foods for a few days but then would eat (organic if possible) red meat in small amounts as i felt i needed it (i would dream of hamburgers!), also bone broths.  The more i forced myself to move - walk/gym/stretch the less tired i got.  I fasted for 1 day before and on the day of EC and lab/clinical research suggests this is likely to make treatment more effective and possibly protect your own cells -  particularly for any affecting digestion - i did it every time so no idea if it did but certainly didn't want to stop to see if things would get worse!   Paclitaxel so far has been a dream - i feel tired on the day because of the anti-histamines and then have a couple of 'zippy' days because of the steroids but have felt pretty normal. I fast only the night before and the day of and i have experimented with this - if i start to eat on the day of chemo i get pretty instant diarrhoea and if i wait until the next day i don't. I do have a small amount of burning feeling in my feet - its so far not bad and goes after day 4 but i'm aware (and slightly scared!) that i know Paclitaxel builds up over the weeks and side  effects like neuropathy get worse so i am keeping an eye on it. I am using something called Polybalm which is supposed to protect against nail damage.   I am eating throughout all this with the help of one of the latest books on nutrition (published in April) -  the only one my extremely picky (scientist) partner agrees has very robust research behind it and to me makes complete sense and is very reassuring and flexible: Eat to Beat Disease by William Li.  I also have found pure shea butter the best moisturiser for dry skin and great for massaging surgery scars - mine really seem to need a pretty firm hand to stop the area tightening up! Also i got a wig through referral from my oncology team to the wig fitting service at the hospital - this allowed me £250 towards a wig (which makes many of them completely free or makes a human hair wig more affordable).  I then got mine styled by the wonderful Trevor Sorbie himself as part of his charity open to all "My New Hair' which is an amazing thing!  Also i have taken advantage of free complementary therapies at the amazing Breast Cancer Haven (there are various branches) and found acupuncture really helps with any nausea and fatigue and general feeling better! Finally for anyone who doesn't know, your oncologist can sign you off work and as long as you are on chemo.  There are various means tested benefits you can get but if you have been paying your NI everyone, no matter what you earn or savings you have, is entitled to New style Employment Support allowance.  Macmlllan finance team can help.  Its not much, but as i'm depending on my partner at the moment its just enough to not make me feel completely like I'm bringing nothing in! Anyway sorry for the long post - i just thought, i'm halfway through (almost) and some of this might be helpful!  Big love to every amazing person on here - i'm so inspired by the courage, support, humour and sheer bloody hard work that people are putting into fighting this f****ing hideous disease- thank you so much for posting -  you all are the most help i've had!  xxxx
Posts.Title: **MAY 2019 BREAST CANCER CHEMOTHERAPY CHAT**

Posts.Content: Hi Lisa, I haven’t had the experience of chemo at home, but personally I wouldn’t choose it simply because I would want to keep all the chemo stuff firmly at hospital leaving my home as my home with a nice dividing line. However maybe you live a fair way from the hospital in which case it may make sense. I have had EC x4 every two weeks and now in the middle of 12x weekly Paclitaxel, with both of these I didn’t have any immediate reactions and was perfectly able to walk home, but everyone is different.. and yes it is nice to chat to people on the day and see others going through similar - it helps me keep perspective when I’m feeling a bit sorry for myself! Hope that might be helpful! And also: looking at chemo as an unknown quantity ahead of  you is particularly scary so big hugs to you and don’t worry too much- it is all pants no matter how you look at it but one day at a time you will get through as so many others have. xxxx
Posts.Title: **MAY 2019 BREAST CANCER CHEMOTHERAPY CHAT**
